tips.tip: Pepcid (famotidine) 20mg is safer long-term GERD medication than PPIs (omeprazole, esomeprazole). Take 30 minutes before dinner once daily - 'works great,' no side effects, 'very safe,' and benefits outweigh risks per multiple doctors. PPIs suppress acid BUT you still reflux, and long-term use not recommended (meant for short-term only). PPIs affect kidney function (GFR drops to 50s) which reverses after stopping.
tips.notes: Michele Burke: Pepcid 'works great,' no side effects, OK for long-term. Meg Hadcock: Both omeprazole and rabeprazole affected kidney function (GFR 50s), returned to normal after stopping. Kathleen: PPIs suppress acid but don't stop reflux.

tips.tip: Lifestyle changes CANNOT control GERD for everyone - 'not everyone can control GERD with lifestyle changes. I'm trying everything, still have it.' Some patients in severe pain from heartburn despite trying everything. Silent reflux adds complexity. While weight loss, caffeine/alcohol abstention, and postural/eating/sleeping changes work for some, medication or surgery may be necessary for severe cases.
tips.notes: Pooja in severe pain, can't manage with lifestyle alone, considering surgery. Others control successfully with diet/postural changes. Important: validate that severe GERD requires medical intervention.

tips.tip: Nissen fundoplication/LINX/TIF surgery risks: 25% of fundoplication patients develop gastroparesis and other GI problems requiring correction procedure (G-poem). Expect 12-15 lbs weight loss from 3-week post-surgery liquid diet. Surgery makes MAC treatments more difficult to manage. Worst outcome: back on PPIs after surgery despite complications. Find surgeon who has done MANY procedures, ask for statistics on outcomes/risks, work with clinical nutritionist for food transition. 'Be prepared for the unexpected after surgery.'
tips.notes: Anonymous patient: poor outcome with toupet fundoplication, gastroparesis, back on PPIs. Surgeon said 25% have gastro issues. Surgery should be carefully considered - complications can be severe and long-lasting.

tips.tip: Alkaline water for GERD/laryngopharyngeal reflux: MUST be pH 8.5+ to inactivate pepsin (stomach enzyme causing throat/sinus damage). Drink 1 cup daily + gargle/spit baking soda water morning and evening. Works 'within a week - amazing!' for respiratory reflux. Make your own: 1/8 tsp baking soda to 8 oz purified water, or use ALKAZONE drops (12 drops to 12 oz). Sterilize with UV light (CrazyCAP bottle) if needed. Expert: Dr. Jamie Koufman (books: 'Dropping Acid,' 'Dr. Koufman's Acid Reflux Diet').
tips.notes: Erika: worked within week using pH 8.5+ alkaline water + baking soda gargle. Jan Hanson: ALKAZONE drops, laryngopharyngeal reflux expert Dr. Koufman. WARNING: Lemon/lime juice ACIDIFIES water despite myths about becoming alkaline after ingestion.

tips.tip: Baking soda rinse for oral lichen planus + GERD relief: Rinse mouth several times daily with baking soda and water, especially after coffee. 'Such a simple thing' - calms lichen planus in 2 days, no dentist/oral surgeon/ENT had ever suggested it. Also helps GERD by neutralizing acid/pepsin in mouth and throat. Can use topical steroid gel (Fluocinonide 0.05%) for severe lichen planus ulcers - amount used in mouth won't affect pulmonary NTM.
tips.notes: Rebecca Francis: dental hygienist suggested, worked within 2 days for lichen planus. Also helps with acid reflux damage in mouth/throat. Sue: steroid cream prevents ulcers from becoming cancerous.

tips.tip: Bed elevation for GERD: 30 degrees required per National Jewish and most pulmonologists. Options: (1) Full-length foam wedge between box spring and mattress (80 inches long) - only achieves 8-10 degrees but doesn't cause sliding; (2) 2-2.5 feet wedge pillow achieves 25 degrees; (3) True 30 degree wedge is 11 inches high - patients slide down all night, curled at bottom by morning; (4) 6-inch bed risers under headboard; (5) BackMax full body cushion prevents sliding. Compromise: 3-4 hours between eating and sleeping if can't tolerate elevation.
tips.notes: Mamie measured with phone level app: 80-inch wedge = 8-10°, short wedge = 25°. Lora jo: 30° wedge = 11 inches high, sliding problem universal. Janet Wilson loves/hates BackMax but grateful after traveling with pillows.

tips.tip: Travel GERD management: Can't use adjustable bed or risers when bed attached to headboard. Solutions: (1) Grab sofa cushions or extra pillows, place between mattress and box spring/platform to elevate head; (2) Lift thick mattress high enough to shove pillow underneath (makes bed look weird but helps); (3) Blow-up wedges uncomfortable. Avoid caffeine and give up stubborn food loves (Mary Ann: caffeine is bronchodilator but still must limit).
tips.notes: Donna's 2-month rental solution: pillow under mattress worked. Anonymous: sofa cushions between mattress and platform. Compromise required when traveling.

tips.tip: Postural drainage vs GERD conflict: National Jewish recommending AGAINST postural drainage (lying down), suggesting airway clearance while sitting instead, due to aspiration risk. HOWEVER: 'NOTHING, and I mean nothing, can clear my lungs like postural drainage can.' Compromise: Do postural drainage ONLY on empty stomach (first thing in morning before breakfast), hips elevated 30°, lying on back then turning to sides, 20-30 minutes. Some patients do it in morning before eating, neb in evening sitting up.
tips.notes: Anonymous: postural drainage irreplaceable for clearance despite GERD. Lora jo switched: PD morning empty stomach (avoids food aspiration), neb evening. M. abscessus can be aspirated from food via silent reflux. Policy shift at NJH controversial among patients.

tips.tip: Percussion clapping for postural drainage: Lie on yoga mat, use 'double thumper' percussion vibrator against ribs in various positions (~$50 Amazon). Can produce sputum within 1-2 minutes, up to 30 minutes after stopping. Roll to one side then other while vibrating. Initially uncomfortable against ribs but get used to it. 'Think: can you get more ketchup out of upright container or on its side? Postural drainage WORKS!' Some patients hung upside down on inversion table ('Teeter Table') wearing vest - 'mouthfuls of crude' came out.
tips.notes: RB Sylvester's detailed technique with photos. Works better than vest for him. Extreme version: inversion table upside down. Carol Hurst: also uses vibrator on chest/back, combines with singing in low range (resonates in chest).

tips.tip: Lying flat with GERD for exercise/PT: Do first thing in morning before eating or drinking anything. Spine exercises requiring lying completely flat OK if stomach empty - no time limit specified but 1-2 hours feasible. Schedule dental/medical appointments, CT scans early morning before eating. Drink alkaline water (high pH) before/after to neutralize pepsin enzyme that causes sinus/throat damage. Avoid downward dogs in yoga.
tips.notes: Tracy: all yoga/stretching first thing morning, schedules appointments early before eating. Tammy: alkaline water neutralizes pepsin enzyme to reduce damage. Suzanne needed 1-2 hours daily for spine PT.

tips.tip: Bloating with bronchiectasis: Hyperinflated lungs push down on stomach - 'I do wonder where my stomach actually is anymore.' Common with hiatal hernia. Must eat relatively small portions and stay upright for 3+ hours after eating. Tight band feeling around ribs - 'sometimes hard to tell what organ hurts' when you have hiatal hernia, gastritis, and moderate bronchiectasis together.
tips.notes: Sue: hyperinflated lungs, feels stomach will burst. Barbara Jo and Stephanie: hiatal hernia creates severe bloating, requires small portions and upright positioning 3+ hours.

tips.tip: Reflux Gourmet and Reflux Raft alginates: Alginate products create barrier on top of stomach contents. Mixed reviews on Amazon - some experience heartburn, bloating, nausea, aggravated reflux, indigestion from these products. Used with Dexilant for severe silent reflux. Difference between brands unclear - limited patient experience data available.
tips.notes: Jean Marie just started Reflux Raft with Dexilant for severe silent reflux. Anonymous asked about experiences - concerning Amazon reviews exist. More data needed on effectiveness and side effects.

key_insights: GERD-aspiration-NTM connection is CRITICAL: Silent reflux and overt GERD cause aspiration of stomach contents (including bacteria from food) into lungs. M. abscessus can be aspirated from food. This is why GERD management is not optional for NTM patients - it's infection control. Pepsin (stomach enzyme) damages throat, sinuses, airways even when acid is suppressed by PPIs. Explains why alkaline water (pH 8.5+) works - it inactivates pepsin.

PPI paradox: PPIs (omeprazole, esomeprazole, rabeprazole) suppress stomach acid BUT don't stop reflux - you still aspirate material into lungs. Long-term use causes kidney damage (GFR drops to 50s, reversible after stopping). 'Meant for short-term use only' yet gastroenterologists prescribe indefinitely. Pepcid (famotidine) safer alternative - works for many, no kidney issues, OK long-term per multiple doctors.

Lifestyle changes insufficient for many: Critical to acknowledge 'not everyone can control GERD with lifestyle changes' despite trying everything. Patients in severe pain, considering surgery. Medical community often dismisses need for medication/surgery, assuming dietary/positional changes enough. Reality: GERD severity spectrum wide - some controlled with weight loss and eating schedule, others need aggressive intervention.

Surgery risks underestimated: 25% of fundoplication patients develop gastroparesis requiring corrective G-poem procedure. Post-surgery complications make MAC treatment harder. Worst irony: back on PPIs after surgery despite gastroparesis and other problems. 'Be prepared for unexpected' - surgery not magic solution, can create worse problems. Need surgeon who has done MANY procedures, get statistics, work with clinical nutritionist.

Bed elevation engineering challenge: True 30° elevation (recommended by NJH and most pulmonologists) = 11 inches height = universal sliding problem ('curled at bottom by morning'). Short foam wedges more comfortable but only achieve 8-10° (insufficient). Patients compromise: lower elevation they can tolerate vs. 3-4 hours eating-to-sleeping gap. No perfect solution exists - trade-offs required.

Postural drainage dilemma: National Jewish policy shift AWAY from postural drainage due to aspiration risk, toward sitting airway clearance. BUT patients report 'NOTHING can clear lungs like postural drainage.' Compromise emerging: PD only on empty stomach (first thing morning before eating) to avoid food aspiration while preserving effectiveness. M. abscessus aspiration from food via reflux documented. Timing matters more than position.

Alkaline water pH precision matters: Must be 8.5+ to inactivate pepsin. Lower pH ineffective. Lemon water is ACIDIC despite myths about becoming alkaline after ingestion - tests with pH strips prove this. Make your own: 1/8 tsp baking soda to 8 oz water. Store-bought alkaline water needs UV sterilization (CrazyCAP bottle) for NTM patients. Dr. Jamie Koufman is expert for laryngopharyngeal reflux resources.

Bloating from hyperinflated lungs: Bronchiectasis → air trapping → hyperinflation → lungs push down on stomach/digestive organs. 'Where is my stomach anymore?' Combined with hiatal hernia (common) creates severe bloating, 'tight band around ribs,' difficulty distinguishing which organ hurts. Requires eating small portions, staying upright 3+ hours after meals. Anatomical crowding complicates digestion.

Timing is everything: First thing in morning on empty stomach = safe window for lying flat exercises, postural drainage, dental/medical appointments, yoga/stretching. Neutralize pepsin with alkaline water before/after. 3-4 hours gap between eating and lying down minimum. Schedule life around stomach emptying to prevent aspiration while maintaining necessary activities (ACT, exercise, sleep).

common_questions.question: Is Pepcid safer than omeprazole (Prilosec) or other PPIs for long-term GERD management?
common_questions.answer: Yes, based on multiple patient experiences and doctor recommendations. Pepcid (famotidine) 20mg taken 30 minutes before dinner once daily 'works great,' has no side effects, is 'very safe,' and benefits outweigh risks. PPIs (omeprazole, esomeprazole, rabeprazole) suppress acid BUT you still reflux, and they affect kidney function (GFR drops to 50s) which reverses after stopping. PPIs were 'meant for short-term use only' yet often prescribed indefinitely. Many patients switched from PPIs to Pepcid successfully. However, some people need PPIs - work with your gastroenterologist to determine best option.

common_questions.question: Should I consider fundoplication surgery for my severe GERD?
common_questions.answer: Approach with extreme caution. 25% of fundoplication patients develop gastroparesis and other GI problems requiring additional corrective procedures (G-poem). Expect 12-15 lbs weight loss from mandatory 3-week post-surgery liquid diet. Surgery complications make MAC treatment more difficult to manage. Worst irony: some patients end up back on PPIs after surgery despite having gastroparesis. Before considering: (1) Find surgeon who has done MANY procedures, (2) Ask for their statistics on complications and outcomes, (3) Work with clinical nutritionist for post-surgery food transition, (4) 'Be prepared for the unexpected.' Surgery should be last resort after exhausting medication and lifestyle options.

common_questions.question: How do I make alkaline water for GERD and what pH do I need?
common_questions.answer: Must be pH 8.5 or HIGHER to inactivate pepsin (stomach enzyme causing throat/sinus damage). Two methods: (1) DIY: Add 1/8 teaspoon baking soda to 8 oz purified water, OR (2) ALKAZONE drops: 12 drops to 12 oz water. Drink 1 cup daily. Also gargle and spit baking soda water morning and evening. Works 'within a week' for respiratory reflux. Important: Lemon/lime water is ACIDIC despite myths - pH test strips prove this. Store-bought alkaline water (like 10 Spring Water pH 10) can be used, sterilize with UV light (CrazyCAP bottle) if concerned about NTM. Expert resources: Dr. Jamie Koufman's books 'Dropping Acid' and 'Dr. Koufman's Acid Reflux Diet.'

common_questions.question: What bed elevation angle do I need for GERD and how do I achieve it?
common_questions.answer: 30 degrees is recommended by National Jewish and most pulmonologists, BUT this is extremely difficult to maintain (11 inches height, patients slide down and wake up 'curled at bottom'). Options: (1) Full-length foam wedge between box spring and mattress (80 inches long) - comfortable but only achieves 8-10°, (2) Short 2-2.5 feet wedge pillow achieves 25°, (3) BackMax full body cushion prevents sliding, (4) 6-inch bed risers under headboard, (5) Compromise approach: Use lower elevation you can tolerate + wait 3-4 hours between eating and sleeping. When traveling: place sofa cushions or extra pillows between mattress and box spring/platform.

common_questions.question: Should I stop doing postural drainage if I have GERD?
common_questions.answer: National Jewish is now recommending against postural drainage (lying down) due to aspiration risk, suggesting airway clearance while sitting. HOWEVER, many patients report 'NOTHING, and I mean nothing, can clear my lungs like postural drainage can.' Compromise solution: Do postural drainage ONLY on empty stomach - first thing in morning before eating or drinking anything. This avoids aspirating food/bacteria while preserving effectiveness. Some patients switched to: postural drainage in morning on empty stomach, then nebulizing in evening while sitting. M. abscessus can be aspirated from food via silent reflux, so timing matters. Discuss with your pulmonologist.

common_questions.question: Can I lie flat to do exercises or physical therapy if I have GERD?
common_questions.answer: Yes, but ONLY on empty stomach. Do it first thing in morning before eating or drinking anything. Patients report doing 1-2 hours of spine exercises, yoga, stretching lying flat without problems when stomach is empty. Also schedule dental appointments, medical procedures, CT scans early morning before eating. Drink alkaline water (high pH) before and after to neutralize pepsin enzyme that causes sinus/throat damage. Avoid downward dogs in yoga (head below stomach).

common_questions.question: Why do I have such severe bloating with bronchiectasis?
common_questions.answer: Hyperinflated lungs (from air trapping in damaged airways) push DOWN on your stomach and digestive organs - patients report 'I wonder where my stomach actually is anymore.' Often combined with hiatal hernia (common in BE patients) which makes bloating worse. Creates 'tight band feeling around ribs' and 'sometimes hard to tell what organ hurts.' Management: Eat relatively small portions, stay UPRIGHT for 3+ hours after eating. The anatomical crowding from hyperinflated lungs compressing abdominal organs complicates digestion significantly.

common_questions.question: Does baking soda water help with more than just GERD?
common_questions.answer: Yes! Rinsing mouth several times daily with baking soda water (especially after coffee) calms oral lichen planus within 2 days - 'such a simple thing' that no dentist/oral surgeon/ENT ever suggested. Also neutralizes acid/pepsin in mouth and throat from reflux. Used as gargle morning and evening for respiratory reflux along with drinking alkaline water - works 'within a week.' For severe oral lichen planus ulcers, can use topical steroid gel (Fluocinonide 0.05%) - amount in mouth won't affect pulmonary NTM.

common_questions.question: How do I do percussion clapping for postural drainage?
common_questions.answer: Lie on yoga mat, use 'double thumper' percussion vibrator (~$50 Amazon) against ribs in various positions while rolling to one side then the other. Can produce sputum within 1-2 minutes, continues up to 30 minutes after stopping. Initially uncomfortable directly against ribs but you get used to it. 'Think: can you get more ketchup out of upright container or on its side? Postural drainage WORKS!' Some also use singing in low voice range (resonates in chest), vibrator on back. Extreme version: some patients hung upside down on inversion table wearing vest - got 'mouthfuls of crude' out. Important: ONLY do this on empty stomach to avoid aspiration.

common_questions.question: Can I control my GERD with just lifestyle changes?
common_questions.answer: Not everyone can - this is important to acknowledge. While weight loss, caffeine/alcohol abstention, eating schedule, and sleeping position work for SOME patients, others report 'I'm trying everything, still have it' and are in severe pain despite all lifestyle modifications. GERD severity exists on a spectrum. If lifestyle changes aren't working after sustained effort, don't blame yourself - medication (Pepcid safer than PPIs long-term) or even surgery may be necessary. Silent reflux adds another layer of complexity since you may not have typical heartburn symptoms but still be aspirating. Work with gastroenterologist to find solution that works for YOUR severity level.

common_questions.question: Should I try Reflux Gourmet or Reflux Raft alginates?
common_questions.answer: Limited patient data available. Alginates create physical barrier on top of stomach contents. Used with Dexilant for severe silent reflux. However, Amazon reviews show concerning side effects in some people: heartburn, bloating, nausea, aggravated reflux, indigestion. Difference between brands unclear. May be worth trying under doctor supervision, but be aware that not everyone tolerates them well. Start cautiously and monitor for any worsening of symptoms.
